newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Family and friends mourn Busang geologist.
newsitem.headline: Family and friends mourn Busang geologist.

text.p: Friends and family members held a service in Jakarta on Friday for Filipino geologist Michael de Guzman, who fell out of a helicopter while flying to the Busang gold find he helped discover in Indonesia's East Kalimantan province.
His widow, Theresa Cruz, wept as she stood at the head of the carved wooden casket where a large portrait of de Guzman was placed alongside family photographs and a crucifix.

De Guzman's brother and two sisters were also present at the simple ceremony at the Gatot Subroto hospital in central Jakarta along with John Felderhof, the vice-president of Bre-X Minerals Ltd where de Guzman was chief geologist.

Bre-X shares plunged on Thursday on the Toronto Stock Exchange when trading in the stock reopened after being suspended when the company made a stunning admission there might be far less gold at the Busang property than previously estimated.
Bre-X chief executive David Walsh said in a statement on Wednesday that "there appears a strong possibility that the potential gold resources on the Busang property...have been overstated".
The Calgary-based exploration company announced on February 17 the property contained about 71 million ounces of gold worth some $25 billion at current prices.
The penny-stock company became a darling of the Toronto Stock Exchange as it continued to raise the gold reserve estimate in the Busang property through 1996 and this year.

Bre-X shares were hit last week after news that de Guzman had fallen out of a helicopter while on his way to the Busang property, touted as the biggest single find since gold was discovered on South Africa's Witwatersrand late last century.
Some Indonesian officials have called it a suicide as the helicopter was in good condition and one of the letters de Guzman left behind said he was suffering from acute hepatitis B.
De Guzman's brother, who declined to give his name, said his brother had not given any indication that he had been ill with hepatitis B.
Felderhof, who had worked closely with de Guzman in discovering the Busang property, said his colleague's body would be flown to the Philippines on Saturday.
Reverand F. de van der Schueren, who conducted the prayers, told the small gathering that "Michael had found what he was looking for...the treasure as the Lord would say".
"He went to look for new treasures...he was rewarded, he found it. But it seems God did not want to grant him this reward as better rewards await him," he said.
The Indonesian government has put the Busang gold find on hold after news that the property might contain much less than earlier reported.

The director-general of the mines and energy ministry, Kuntoro Mangkusubroto, said on Thursday he was putting aside applications for contracts of work by Bre-X to further explore and develop the property.
He said the latest turn of events in the long-running Busang saga could dent Indonesia's image and investor confidence.
